body:
ANNOUNCEMENT
Readers: Do you have questions about the political and international scene? Washington Bureau Chief Jerry Seib would be happy to answer them in an upcoming Daybreak video. Send your questions to editor Kate Milani at kate.milani@wsj.com. We look forward to hearing from you!
HIGHLIGHTS
FRENCH AUTHORITIES RAID SUSPECTED ISLAMISTS AFTER PARIS ATTACKS: French police fanned out Monday to search the homes of suspected radical Islamists, pledging to crack down on extremists hours after conducting airstrikes on Islamic State targets in Syria in response to the attacks that rocked Paris. The rapidly moving investigation is revealing a picture of a network of terrorists, many of them born in Europe, who were trained in Syria or elsewhere in the Middle Eastâa scenario that has worried authorities across Europe for years.
Belgian and French authorities are also investigating whether a Belgian man suspected of being the mastermind behind a foiled Belgian terrorist plot in January orchestrated Fridayâs onslaught, officials familiar with the probe said. Abdelhamid Abaaoud, who was raised in Brussels, may have escaped to Syria after police shot and killed two men in the eastern Belgian town of Verviers who were plotting to kill police officers. At least several of the suspects had moved undetected by both the French and Belgian governments, using an operating base just 50 miles off Franceâs border, in Brussels. Inti Landauro and Matthew Dalton report.
The latest on the Paris attacks:Â World leaders promised a forceful response to FridayâsÂ terrorist attacks in Paris, including intensified airstrikes against Islamic State militants in Iraq and Syria, intelligence cooperation and measures to tighten border security â¦ The Belgian links to the Paris attacks have reignited concerns that the European Unionâs capital continues to be a breeding ground for radical Islamist terrorists, sparking a debate in the country about whether the government is doing enough to crack down on them … When the sound of a suicide bomber detonating an explosive vest rang out across the Stade de France, President FranÃ§ois Hollande was in the stadium watching Franceâs national soccer team take on Germany. Paris was coming under attack from Islamic State militants, and Mr. Hollande had to decide whether it was safer to evacuate the stadium or keep thousands inside â¦ France and the U.S. have been on opposing trajectories in the Muslim world in recent years â¦ The Paris attacks are transforming Europeâs migration crisis into a security debate, spurring calls for a clampdown on free movement across borders, and putting proponents of an open door for refugees on the defensive … How the attacks unfoldedÂ Â â¦ Portraits of Paris attack victims begin to emerge…The latest updates on the Paris attacks are at the WSJâs liveblog.
AARON ZITNER: PARIS ATTACKS UPEND WHITE HOUSE RACE IN DIFFERENT WAYS FOR EACH PARTY
The terror attacks in Paris have injected an emotional and unexpected element into the U.S. presidential race. But they are likely to affect the two parties in different ways, Aaron Zitner reports. Read Aaron Zitner’s full post in Washington Wire.
WSJ STORIES YOU SHOULDN’T MISS
PARIS TRAGEDY COULD SHAKE UP 2016 RACE: The terrorist attacks in Paris could shake up the 2016 presidential race, reminding voters of the high stakes and potentially boosting candidates who put their governing experience front and center. During much of the campaign, voters have swooned over candidates who trumpet their nonpolitical rÃ©sumÃ©s. Celebrity businessman Donald Trump and retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson have led the Republican field, running far ahead of politicians who served in statehouses and Congress. On the Democratic side, self-described socialist Bernie Sanders has been drawing the largest and most enthusiastic crowds, putting a scare into the establishment candidate, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton. The Paris attacks and potency of Islamic State, which France blames for the deadly assaults, could reshuffle the field as voters ask: Is this the moment to turn over the presidency to an untested outsider? Peter Nicholas and Beth Reinhard report.
Plus:Â Democrats and Republicans, based on their recent presidential debates, are set to offer voters a stark choice in 2016 about how the economy should be managed, with both sides moving toward the outer flanks of their partiesÂ â¦ Republican presidential candidates have criticized Mrs. ClintonÂ for decliningÂ to use term such as âradical Islamâ and âIslamic terrorismâÂ to describe the extremists who have unleashed a string of terrorist attacks on Western targets recentlyÂ â¦ Sen. Bernie Sanders had one clear mission in the presidential debateÂ SaturdayÂ night: Put Mrs. Clinton on the defensive in hopes of peeling away Democratic voters who are coalescing behind her candidacy. That didnât happen â¦ Still, Democrats who watched the partyâs presidential candidates debate thought that Mr. Sanders won the event, an Internet survey found, though they also said Mrs. Clinton showed that she would do the best job of keeping the U.S. safe from terrorism.
OBAMA FACES A CROSSROADS: President Obama came into office with a single, driving foreign-policy principle that shaped his approach to international crises: Avoid another protracted war like those in Iraq and Afghanistan. Fridayâs terrorist attacks in Paris, which killed at least 129 people, present Mr. Obama with a fundamental test of whether the approach is sustainable. With one year in office remaining, the president faces pressure to escalate what is now seen as a global, rather than regional, fight against Islamic State militants, whom France accused of carrying out the attacks. How Mr. Obama responds, in coordination with Americaâs European allies and potentially Russia, could define U.S. leadership for years to come. Carol E. Lee reports.
Plus:Â The White House said the U.S. agrees with France that the terrorist attacks in Paris are âan act of warâ and demands stronger international commitments to combat the Islamic State group that carried out the attacks … The Paris terror attacks suggest that the U.S. and its allies overestimated recent successes against Islamic State while underestimating the groupâs ability to strike far from its Middle East stronghold, according to U.S. lawmakers, analysts and former senior intelligence officialsÂ â¦ Thirty minutes of terror on the streets of Paris looks to become the catalyst for a broad shift in international politics with implications that could last for years.
TRUMP COURTS GOP VOTERS IN FLORIDA: Donald Trump is staking claim to a state that helped cinch the last two GOP presidential nominations, barreling past a couple of native sons in the race. At a weekend gathering of hundreds of Florida Republican activists, he elicited a rowdier reception than Sen. Marco Rubio and former Gov. Jeb Bush and he is leading them in statewide polls. âIâm not leading them. Iâm trouncing them,â corrected Mr. Trump in an interview Friday with The Wall Street Journal, pulling a list of the latest polling from his breast pocket. Mr. Trump is favored by 27% of state GOP voters, while Mr. Rubioâs standing is at 16% and Mr. Bush has the support of 9%, according to the Real Clear Politics polling average. Floridaâs winner-take-all primary will award 99 delegatesâroughly 8% of the total needed to clinch the nominationâand is viewed as a must-win for Messrs. Rubio and Bush. While Mr. Trump has never held public office in Florida, he isnât trespassing either. Beth Reinhard reports.
Plus:Â Sen. Ted Cruz brought his presidential campaign to an evangelical bastion Saturday, traveling to Bob Jones University to hold a religious liberty rally that was shadowed by anxiety about the terrorist attacks in Paris.
ALSO IN THE NEWS
Lawmakers and the Obama administration are ratcheting up efforts to target pharmaceutical companies over high-priced drugs, a sign that legislators are trying to bridge partisan differences to tackle a key driver of rising health care costs.
A year ago, the financial industry stirred up a political furor by inserting relief from post-crisis regulation into a catch-all year-end spending bill. As Congress scrambles to wrap up its budget for this year, banks and their political allies are again angling to insert unrelated rule-reduction measuresâand bracing for a new battle.
The worldâs biggest energy companies have doubled down on their promise to protect dividends, despite a precipitous drop in profits this year, driven by a steep decline in oil prices.
As Paris reeled fromÂ FridayÂ nightâs terrorist attacks, life in New York over the weekend carried on largely as normal. But many, whether or not they had family and friends in France, said the attacks had cast a shadow over their own lives, and brought up their own uncertainties and fears.
Facebook said it will use its âsafety checkâ tool more widely after activating it during the terrorist attacks in ParisÂ Friday. But deciding when to implement the feature could push the social network into sensitive territory.
The U.S. transferred five Yemeni detainees from the prison facility at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba to the United Arab Emirates, the Pentagon announced lateÂ Sunday.
Civic groups in Illinois are pressing top elected officials to start meeting as a state budget stalemate stretches into its fifth month, with fallout affecting operations ranging from social services to paying for holiday lights.
With online sales taking up a greater share of the retail pie, merchants, mall owners and economists will be looking to data due outÂ TuesdayÂ for signs of a shift in buying habits that could point to further changes in Americaâs shopping infrastructure.
The head of the Russian Athletics Federation saidÂ on SundayÂ he hoped to restore Russiaâs membership in track and fieldâs international federation within three months to allow the countryâs athletes to compete in the 2016 Summer Olympics.
Weapons were missing following a break-in at an Army Reserve center in Worcester, Mass., an FBI spokeswoman said.
TODAY’S VIDEO
SEIB VIDEO: LEADERS TO SHARE THEIR VIEWS AT WSJ CEO COUNCIL
WSJ’s Jerry Seib discusses what to look for as business and government leaders gather at The Wall Street Journal’s CEO Council this week, with House Speaker Paul Ryan and Sen. Marco Rubio set to appear.
HERE’S A LOOK AT THE DAY AHEAD
OBAMA ADMINISTRATION: President Barack Obama leaves Antalya, Turkey, where the G20 summit has been held, and travels to the Philippines for the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation summit.
CONGRESS: The House and Senate return from the Veterans Day recess.
WSJ CEO COUNCIL: Republican presidential candidate Sen. Marco Rubio (R., Fla.) and Defense Secretary Ash Carter speak at the WSJâs CEO Council Monday evening.
WHAT WE’RE READING AROUND THE WEB
David O’Sullivan, the European Union’s ambassador to the U.S., warns that the terror attacks in Paris could bring back forces of “extreme nationalism and hatred” in Europe, destroying the continents hard-won unity, writes John Hudson of Foreign Policy.
“Efforts to blunt ISIS propaganda have been tentative and ineffective, despite major efforts by countries like Saudi Arabia, the United States and the United Kingdom, and even al-Qaida,” writes Alberto M. Fernandez of Brookings.
SaturdayÂ night’s Democratic debate showed that “regardless of how the horse race evolves,” Sen. Bernie Sanders “is now making the case for progressive policies in a manner that the United States hasnât seen in decades,” writes The New Yorker’s John Cassidy.
Islamic State is wants to keep its territory in Iraq and Syria, and has begun using tactical skills it learned in fighting there âto provoke an anti-Muslim backlash that will generate even more recruits within Western societies,â writes Harleen Gambhlr in The Washington Post.
In WSJâs Think Tank, Brian Katulis writes that the fight against Islamic extremists can be won, but the U.S. needs âto decide that we are going to show up and stick around.â
FEEDBACK: The Capital Journal Daybreak newsletter is The Wall Street Journal’s morning rundown of the biggest news stories and exclusive features from Washington on politics, policy, financial regulation, defense and more. Send your tips, feedback and suggestions for recommended reading to editor Kate Milani at kate.milani@wsj.com.

description: French police fanned out Monday to search the homes of suspected radical Islamists, hours after conducting airstrikes on Islamic State targets in Syria in response to Friday's attacks in Paris, and more in  Capital Journal Daybreak.
title: Capital Journal Daybreak: French Authorities Raid Suspected Islamists
